questiontext.text:
Example

Obtain expressions for \(\cos\theta\) in terms of the sine function and for \(\sin\theta\) in terms of the cosine function.

Solution

Using

\[\cos (A-B)\equiv \cos A\cos B+\sin A\sin B\]

with \(A=\theta,\ B=\dfrac{\pi}{2}\) we obtain

\[ \cos\left(\theta-\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)\equiv\cos\theta\ \cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)+\sin\theta\ \sin \left (\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)\equiv \cos\theta\ (0)+\sin \theta\ \]

i.e.

\[\sin\theta\equiv\cos\left(\theta-\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)\equiv\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right)\]

This result explains why the graph of \(\sin\theta\) has exactly the same shape as the graph of \(\cos\theta\) but it is shifted to the right by \(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\). A similar calculation yields

\[\cos\theta\equiv\sin\left(\theta+\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right).\]
